From $2/day to getting acknowledged by Obama and Bill Gates:

My AI insights can propel your business from thriving to dominating in as little as 90 days!

Attention: Visionary Entrepreneurs Or Savvy Business Leaders

If your business is generating $5M+ in annual revenueâ€¦ but youâ€™re still unsure if your company is truly prepared to take advantage of the AI revolutionâ€¦

Then this will be the most important message youâ€™ll read this month.

The harsh reality is that the business landscape is changing at the speed of light, and those who seize this moment will redefine the future (and get the lionâ€™s share).

How do I know?

Hi, Iâ€™m Manuj Aggarwal, an AI pioneer whose work has been celebrated by luminaries like Barack Obama and Bill Gates.

With over 20 years of hands-on experience, 4 AI patents, and a proven track record of driving $500M+ in value for global giants like Microsoft, IBM, and T-Mobile, I specialize in turning bold ideas into transformative realities.

But it wasnâ€™t always like that.

My journey began in a small Indian factory, slaving my bottom for $2 a day.

Today, I share stages with world leaders, and I advise 8-, 9-, and even 10-figure companies.

Some recent talks were at venues like the United Nations and Cornell University.

In other words, I donâ€™t just understand innovation. I live and breathe it.

Now, Iâ€™m offering something I havenâ€™t ever done and will probably never do again.: a complimentary AI Readiness Assessment for your business.

Imagine your business optimized with cutting-edge AI strategies,

â€¢ Driving growth of up to 40% within months
â€¢ Unprecedented efficiency reducing operational costs by up to 60%
â€¢ Unlocking hidden growth opportunities
â€¢ And positioning you as a market leader

Picture having a tailor-made roadmap that reveals actionable insights you can implement immediately.

All while winning back an ENTIRE day every week and without paying a single dime upfront.

â€œWhatâ€™s the catch, Manuj? Because there has to be a catch, right?â€

Well, I understand that the best form of marketing is word-of-mouth marketing.

So, I have a super simple request. If you find value in all the advice Iâ€™ll provide to you to scale your business, I ask for one of these things in return:

â€¢ An introduction to another $5M+ ARR business that could benefit from my expertise.
â€¢ An invitation to speak on your podcast, at your event, or to your community.
â€¢ A mention of my name and podcast to your network, your list.

And if you donâ€™t find any value (which has never happened before), you donâ€™t have to do anything.

If youâ€™d like to take advantage of this offer, here are the next steps:

â€¢ Verify my credentials - simply Google my name or review my LinkedIn profile
â€¢ Message me or comment below to secure your complimentary AI Readiness Assessment.

And if you have any questions, drop them below.

posts.name:
ğŸ¦¾Jepson Taylor
ğŸ¦¾Jepson Taylor
posts.content:
A thought I've been having lately: yes "AI is the great enabler" we all agree. Everyone can do AI now, isn't that great! I actually think the gap between the top AI researchers has never been further from the average than now. I think 2025 will be a year of increased layoffs for data science teams that were comfortable doing data science the way we all did it before the agent revolution.

To survive as a future data scientist your programming skills will have to level up. Self-adaptive agents is not a strong suit of most data scientists, how many data scientists do you know that can say they are experts at genetic programming? How many are truly full stack? My experience has been very few. AutoML pipelines? Yes! Oh wait, an LLM does all of that now better than most of us ever did. As AI eats the market there will always be jobs for the top 10% in the AI talent pool, but the average will be on increasingly thin ice and the goal line to be in the top 10% will only accelerate ahead of all of us.

Data science is no longer the 'sexist job of the 21st century', now it is agentic/adaptive developers. They do in a week what everyone used to do in months and that amount of work is only accelerating. A year from now agentic programmers would expect to 10x their current pace which was already 10x their peers, the new 100x engineer coming online in 2025.

comments.commentText:
Alternative take: AI can be tested in a very rigorous manner. I'm doing it now; results to be published as soon as I finish the project.

Decide on a mid-level IT project, like a migration of software from Windows to Linux. Choose one you need done for your own business to enhance the value of this exercise.

Make any of the available AIs, starting with a prompt, show you exactly how to do it, command-by-command, write out the exact steps in order. Try it, and test the results.

Suddenly, you'll see, in spectacular clarity, exactly what AI really is and what it is worth. If you want to be realistic about AI and blow away all the silly hype, this is how you go about it.

Good luck!

posts.commentAdded: This insightful perspective highlights the evolving landscape of data science! Adapting and upskilling will be crucial for future success.

posts.content:
Your mental health is your top priority.
Ignoring it comes with a higher cost than you think.

Studies from the American Psychological Association (APA) reveal that chronic stress without proper rest increases anxiety, depression, and even physical health problems like heart disease.

Taking time to rest doesnâ€™t make you weak; it makes you resilient.

When you set boundaries and protect your peace, you give yourself the space to heal, recharge, and show up as your best self.

You deserve the same care and compassion you give to others.

Your peace matters. Your rest matters.

And most importantly, you matter.

Mental health isnâ€™t a luxury. Itâ€™s necessary for survival.

Take the rest you deserve.

Let's kickoff 2025 with intention and momentum.

Signup for our free weekly simple, actionable tips & tools to help you navigate business and personal transitions here:



If you found this post helpful, please repost it with your network.

Always walking with you, because your journey matters

posts.name:
Tony E. Kula
Tony E. Kula
posts.content:
Pitch Panic 

With tomorrowâ€™s open mic pitch event just around the corner, I canâ€™t help but remember how hard it used to be for me to speak in public.

The shaky voice, sweaty palms, and racing heart were all too familiar.

Hereâ€™s what helped me:

 Practice makes perfect

Test your pitch or speech with a friend. Their feedback not only improves your content but also helps you feel more prepared.

 Start with a relatable icebreaker

Share a light personal anecdote or a simple question related to your topic. It relaxes both you and the audience - but donâ€™t force humor if it doesnâ€™t feel natural.

 Focus on one friendly face

Scan the room and find someone who looks kind or encouraging. Making eye contact with that person can help you feel like youâ€™re having a conversation instead of addressing a crowd.

 Shift your perspective

The audience is made up of humans - just like you. Theyâ€™re not there to judge you; theyâ€™re there to listen, learn, and connect.

 Breathe before you begin

Take a few deep breaths to ground yourself. Slow breathing reduces anxiety and gives your voice more control.

 Keep it simple

Donâ€™t overcomplicate your message. Speak clearly, and if you forget something, keep going - most people wonâ€™t even notice.

And above all, remind yourself:
Youâ€™re there to share something valuable, not to be perfect.

Authenticity resonates far more than flawless delivery.

Good luck and if youâ€™re in Berlin tomorrow would love to hear your pitch (see comments).

What helps you to speak on stage?

__________________________

Sharing my experience as an entrepreneur and angel investor.

Investing in early-stage B2B SaaS startups.

Follow for more posts like this.

comments.commentText: https://www.eventbrite.de/e/open-mic-pitch-by-reaktorberlin-tickets-1144212383039?aff=oddtdtcreator

When I worked at Deutsche Bank, I was fortunate to have trained under Patsy Rodenburg. Three key pillars to impactful public speaking:

1. Technique (breathing, warm up voice, body posture, pauses, etc)
2. Knowledge (of subject matter)
3. Confidence (mojo)

Rinse & repeat!
Cassandra age â€¦

posts.commentAdded: Great tips for conquering stage fright! Remembering the audience is there to connect makes all the difference. Good luck to everyone pitching!

Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
posts.content:
In moments of crisis, ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—®ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—µğ—¶ğ—½ is tested in profound ways. 

Itâ€™s not about being flawless or having all the answersâ€”itâ€™s about showing up with empathy and presence.

During challenging times, your team doesnâ€™t need perfection; they need a leader who is grounded, compassionate, and willing to stand with them.

ğ—¦ğ—¼, ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ—±ğ—¼ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—®ğ—± ğ—²ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—® ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜€?

1ï¸âƒ£ Support Their Well-Being
Prioritize your teamâ€™s mental and emotional health.
Check in regularly, ask how theyâ€™re doing, and offer flexibility where possible to ease their stress.

2ï¸âƒ£ Adapt and Be Flexible
Be willing to adjust timelines, work conditions, or schedules to reduce pressure.
Leading with adaptability shows your team that youâ€™re in tune with their needs.

3ï¸âƒ£ Be Transparent
Create open lines of communication.
Share updates honestly and encourage your team to voice their concerns or ideas. Transparency builds trust during uncertainty.

4ï¸âƒ£ Unite for Common Goals
Focus your teamâ€™s energy on shared objectives.
Whether itâ€™s completing a project or supporting a meaningful cause, rallying together strengthens bonds and provides a sense of purpose.

Your actions during a crisis leave a lasting impression.
Ask yourself:
"How can I make this easier for my team?"

Itâ€™s not about always having the solutionâ€”itâ€™s about being present, listening, and showing empathy.

As the saying goes:
â€œYour team may forget what you said, but theyâ€™ll never forget how you made them feel.â€

Lead with heart, and youâ€™ll inspire resilience in others. ï¸

ï¸ Found this helpful? Repost to share with your network.

Followfor more insights on career and leadership growth.

posts.name:
Kevin "KD" Dorsey
Kevin "KD" Dorsey
posts.content:
There are certain ingredients that are needed for success. 

I love the recipe analogy because it allows for multiple things to be true.

Certain dishes have specific recipes, and if you remove an ingredient the recipe falls apart.

But can you add different flavors to a recipe?

Yes.

This isn't about restriction, it's about upliftings.

It's about finding the ingredients to success and sharing with your org to help level them up.

and I talk about how to use AI to do just that - give it a watch

comments.commentText:
Great message. I believe right now people are creating the repeatable C players... AKA AI Sales bots and assistants.

Theoretically if the tech gets better... cooking up some B players out of an AI bot "should" be an easy thing to do if you know your ingredients.

And just to be clear... I don't think AI ever beats the A players. A players always find a way to win!
Ken Collins agree. AI is a looong way from beating A's

Can't beat someone that is so far in front of you in the race... all you can do is follow their lead and hope you finish close to second.

The A players are the trail blazers. They are the ones that produce the ingredients list to train the AI on.

That's why the best written AI is produced by great writers and the best AI code is produced by great developers. And the best AI sales will obviously be done by an A player salesperson that figures out how to best replicate themselves as a B player AI army.

Kevin "KD" Dorsey "I believe everyone can be good but not everyone can be great"

Literally was talking to my wife about exactly this this morning!

The recipe helps get everyone to baseline but then the truly elite take it to the next level!
Ken Collins oh god. dying!

posts.commentAdded: Love this analogy! Success is indeed a blend of essential ingredients and unique flavors. Excited to explore how AI can elevate our recipes for growth!

posts.name:
Daren Lauda
Daren Lauda
posts.content:
One of my earliest formal lessons in leadership occurred when I was 19. I still apply this lesson today.

I was in the Army and attended the Primary Leadership Development Course (PLDC).

I learned the 4 Câ€™s of Leadership: Courage, Candor, Commitment, and Competence.

Here is what the 4 Câ€™s mean to me today.

Courage: I need to have the courage to take risks, explore new things, and face the possibility of failure. I also need to have the courage to question my own thinking and encourage others to do the same.

Candor: I need to be open, honest, and direct in my communication. Just as importantly, I expect the same level of honesty from others. I encourage those around me to provide feedback, even if itâ€™s feedback I might not want to hear.

Commitment: When I take on a new endeavor, I fully commit to it. I work hard and lead by example. However, I have a long history of failing personal commitmentsâ€”such as health and fitness. I am working on that.

Competence: I strive to be an expert in my product and field. I pursue continuous learning, which has been ongoing as I have advanced through content management, product lifecycle management, customer relationship management, supply chain management, and more.

I imagine the Army has evolved leadership lessons over the past few decades.

And I hope straightforward lessons like the 4 Câ€™s are still taught.

I found this old photo. I am under that Chinook, helping with a sling load in Central America. I won't comment on the decade!)
posts.commentAdded: Great insights on the 4 Cs of Leadership! Its inspiring to see how these principles continue to shape your journey. Thank you for sharing!

posts.name:
PRADEEP KUMAR GUPTAA
PRADEEP KUMAR GUPTAA
posts.content:
Have you ever witnessed someone go to extreme lengths to impress a client?

A few weeks ago, we were burning the midnight oil at the officeâ€”coffee cups piling up, final edits flying across screensâ€”when our teammate Neeraj decided to go all-in for an important meeting with a foreign client.

The next morning, he showed up in a suit so sharp it could slice through steel, paired with a tie that screamed â€œI mean business!â€ But the real show started when the video call began.

Neeraj transformed into someone we barely recognized. He was overly formal, tried out a slightly questionable accent, and even threw in phrases like â€œLetâ€™s circle back on thisâ€ (which he never said). His enthusiasm was palpable, but his laptop looked like it might overheat from the sheer intensity of the moment.

As his friends, we were dying from laughter on the sidelines. Someone whispered, â€œIs that Neeraj or James Bond?â€ Another joked his tie was so tight it might be cutting off his circulation.

But hereâ€™s the kicker: the client didnâ€™t even notice the theatrics. They were too busy nodding along to the genuine ideas Neeraj shared later in the call.

-----
Hereâ€™s what this taught us:

Sometimes, in our quest to impress othersâ€”clients, colleagues, or even strangersâ€”we lose sight of what truly matters: authenticity. People connect with who you are, not who youâ€™re pretending to be.

So hereâ€™s my question for you:
- Have you ever gone overboard trying to impress someone at work?
- Whatâ€™s the most hilarious or awkward thing youâ€™ve seen someone do in a professional setting?

Drop your stories in the comments belowâ€”letâ€™s share a laugh and remind each other that being real always wins!

P.S. Watch the video attached for a good laughâ€”itâ€™s Someone else at his finest!

comments.commentText: I'm always amazed by the lengths some people will go to impress a client. Can you share any details about what Neeraj did?

Sure, Neeraj went all out for a video call with a foreign client. He showed up in a sharp suit and tie, tried out a questionable accent, and used phrases he never said before. His enthusiasm was palpable, but his laptop looked like it might overheat from the intensity. However, the client didn't even notice the theatrics and focused on the genuine ideas Neeraj shared later in the call. It's a reminder that authenticity is key in connecting with others. Have you ever gone overboard trying to impress someone at work? What did you learn from that experience?

What a relatable story PRADEEP



Authenticity truly wins every time. Neerajâ€™s transformation is both hilarious and a great lesson!

Absolutely agree! Neeraj's transformation was definitely a sight to see, but it's a great reminder that authenticity is key in building genuine connections with clients and colleagues. In fact, studies have shown that authenticity in the workplace leads to higher job satisfaction and productivity. Have you ever experienced the benefits of being authentic at work? How do you cultivate authenticity in your professional relationships?

posts.content:
How 30$ changed his Life:


He never wanted to be ordinary in life.

2020: He learned graphic design and started his Freelancing career in June 2020.

He was all set, skilled and optimistic, to make money.

Little did he know, the Freelancing world is filled with skilled professionals.

But only a fraction of freelancers could really get the projects.

He kept hustling, bidding on projects, every single day, for more than a month.

Until he got his first project:

He did a flyer design project and made the first earnings of his life: 30$.

That 30$ didnâ€™t change his life. But the courage it brought along, really did.

After almost 5 years of hustle, I can say the whole Business world is the same as the Freelancing world.

Where there is a massive number of:

1. Skilled Professionals
2. Exceptional Products
3. Coolest Systems and Processes

But still, only those who know their customer really well, and how to sell, make money.

2025: Fast forward to almost 5 years, the same guy who could not get clients, now helps Founders:

â†’ Know their customer like their oldest friend.
â†’ Get more qualified leads and book meetings
â†’ And all this with pay-per-lead ( 0% Risk )

So your customers or clients know the potential of your business and YOU.

Your biggest opportunity lies in your biggest struggle.

The Most Asked Question Lately: How Has the Recruiting Industry Changed?



Surprisingly, one of the biggest shifts weâ€™re seeing is a surge in companies entrusting us with their entry- and mid-level rolesâ€”positions they previously handled in-house.

Why the change?

As one business owner explained: â€œWe used to post an ad for an entry-level or mid-level role and get a handful of resumesâ€”manageable, easy to sort through. But now? Weâ€™re flooded with applications, most of which arenâ€™t relevant.â€

Sorting through hundreds of resumes is time-consuming, and companies are realizing they donâ€™t need more applicantsâ€”they need the right candidate. Thatâ€™s where we come in.

When clients work with us, theyâ€™re not just getting resumes. Theyâ€™re getting:

 A dedicated recruiter who knows their business inside and out.
 A carefully headhunted, pre-screened ideal candidateâ€”not a stack of random applications.
 A streamlined hiring process that allows them to focus on growing their business instead of drowning in paperwork.

This shift is happening across industries. Companies that once relied on us only for executive hires are now handing us their mid- and entry-level roles because they trust our recruiters to deliver quality over quantity.

At, every recruiter works with specific clients, in specific industries, and in specific locationsâ€”building relationships, understanding company culture, and ensuring each hire is the perfect fit.
